block.p: The Supreme Court struck down a 1996 law requiring cable systems to limit sex channel transmissions to late-night hours, when children would be less likely to watch, if they could not prevent signals from those channels from ''bleeding'' through to nonsubscribers.
The justices all agreed that shielding children from graphic sex on cable TV was a valid goal, but split 5 to 4 over what limits the First Amendment placed on achieving it.

The Supreme Court struck down a 1996 law requiring cable systems to limit sex channel transmissions to late-night hours, when children would be less likely to watch, if they could not prevent signals from those channels from ''bleeding'' through to nonsubscribers.
The justices all agreed that shielding children from graphic sex on cable TV was a valid goal, but split 5 to 4 over what limits the First Amendment placed on achieving it.

Under another section of the law, cable systems must provide individual blocking devices on request, and the majority said this was more respectful of individual choice and less burdensome on free expression.
